February 7, 1923
Dear Doctor Carter:
div1.p:
Since our talk with you in December about the question
of compensation for your work in writing the history of yellow
fever, the question of the legality of the Board's paying you
compensation while you are Assistant Surgeon General on waiting
orders has been taken up with Surgeon General Cumming. He has ad-
vised us that there is no legal obstacle in the way. The matter
was therefore presented to the Executive Committee at its meeting
yesterday, and it was voted that compensation should be provided
at the rate of $500 per month during the time in which you are en-
gaged in work in connection with the history of yellow fever.

It is our understanding that you do not wish to feel
tied down to regular work on the history. It will be quite satis-
factory to us to have Miss Carter keep track of approximately the
time that you put in on this work, and to have her send us word
from time to time so that payment can be made accordingly. On
the basis of her letter of December 18, we figure that you spent
Doctor Carter
February 7, 1923
2
approximately six months in work on the history during 1922.
I am accordingly requesting the Comptroller to send you $3,000
to cover the time spent during 1922.

We shall count on your daughter to let us know about
the time spent so far this year. We shall expect you also to
keep a record of your incidental expenses incurred in connection
with the history.
With cordial good wishes, I am
div1.closer:
Very sincerely yours, Wickliffe Rose. Doctor H. R. Carter
2121 California Street, N.W.
Washington, D. C.
